title-group.article-title: Continuum damage mechanics application in low-cycle thermal fatigue

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology, Iran

author-notes.corresp: M Mashayekhi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology, 8415683111, Iran. Email: mashayekhi@cc.iut.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012. Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this article, a fatigue model for low-cycle thermal fatigue formulated in a continuum damage mechanics framework is presented. The model is based on a unified damage law presented by Lemaitre for low-cycle fatigue, which has been extended to low-cycle thermal fatigue. The temperature dependencies of material parameters are considered in the damage evolution integration to take the non-isothermal condition of loading into account. This model considers the stress triaxiality and non-linearity of damage evolution, and it is developed to a fatigue damage accumulation rule in which the load sequence effect is also included. The stabilized structural response under thermomechanical loading motivates the use of uncoupled analysis approach making the model a fast tool suitable for design purposes in the costly and time-consuming field of thermomechanical fatigue life assessment. To demonstrate the capability and ease of use of this model for real industrial applications, the low-cycle thermal fatigue life of a stainless steel engine exhaust manifold which is in an early stage of design is assessed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In comparison with high-cycle fatigue (HCF), low-cycle fatigue (LCF) failures may occur when structures are subjected to heavy cyclic loadings which induce lower number of cycles to failure (N < 10,000) because of irreversible plastic strains (Stephens et al., 2000). While LCF can result from repeated large strains at constant temperature conditions, it is frequently created where the repeated stresses are of thermal origin.

Mechanical components of engineering structures that operate at elevated temperatures undergo temperature change at the beginning and end of each usage. This easily could be observed in power machineries such as steam turbines and combustion engines, nuclear pressure vessels, chemical refiners, friction break components and even solder joints in electronic boards. The start-stop temperature change produces high thermal gradients and thus high thermal stresses and strains which may lead to failure in a low number of cycles.

Thermomechanical fatigue (TMF) and thermal fatigue (TF) show a lot of similarity with low-cycle fatigue, mainly because of the presence of cyclic plastic strain and low frequency of loading to failure. This is why these are also referred to as low-cycle thermal fatigue (LCTF). The former is the case of fatigue failure due to simultaneous thermal and mechanical loading (external loads or constraints), while the latter is associated with no external mechanical load where the stresses are self-imposed due to different thermal expansion within a solid brought about by the temperature gradients (Halford, 1986; Viswanathan, 1989).

The main goal of the continuum damage mechanics (CDM) is description of the deterioration phenomena of structures. The field of CDM has advanced to the point where it is an engineering tool. Important developments have occurred in the last decades, contributing to a significant increase in the number of problems modeled using the CDM, such as creep, plastic damage of several materials, fatigue, and creep-fatigue interaction (Jesus et al., 2005; Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005).

CDM, which is known as an effective approach to model ductile failure, can be simply extended to the LCF damage processes (e.g. LCTF), where plasticity is still the key mechanism for the crack initiation (Jesus et al., 1998; Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005). Using this approach the LCTF life of a steam turbine rotor has been assessed by (Ping et al., 2001, 2003).

In this article, Lemaitre’s method for LCF has been extended to the case of LCTF as the non-isothermal LCF. Lemaitre has proposed simplified methods, structured in a unified framework of CDM to designers of any mechanical components with fast calculation of structural failures in different forms of loadings (Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005).

Since in both LCF and LCTF, cyclic strain controlled fatigue occurs and the structures reach a stabilized stress and strain response after a few cycles (Halford, 1986; Stephens et al., 2000; Viswanathan, 1989), the uncoupled analysis approach has been chosen in the model development. This is especially suitable for design purposes in the costly and time-consuming field of TMF life assessment.

The presented model exhibits the non-linearity of damage evolution (Stephens et al., 2000). It is then easily extended to the conditions of variable amplitude loading (VAL) as a fatigue damage accumulation rule which takes into account the load sequence and mean stress effects. Finally the capability and ease of use of this model for the design condition is demonstrated with life assessment of a stainless steel engine exhaust manifold, which is in an early stage of design (Askari, 2009).

sec.title: Continuum damage mechanics approach in low-cycle thermal fatigue
sec.p: In early works, the thermal fatigue resistance of materials was assessed by conducting isothermal LCF tests at the expected maximum temperature of the thermal cycle (Halford, 1986; Stephens et al., 2000; Viswanathan, 1989), where the empirical relation of Coffin-Manson was often employed in analyzing the low-cycle life prediction (Stephens et al., 2000) (1a)Δɛe2=σ'fE(2NR)b (1b)Δɛp2=ɛ'f(2NR)c where Δɛe and Δɛp are respectively the elastic and plastic strain amplitude, σ'f is fatigue strength coefficient, ɛ'f is fatigue ductility coefficient, b and c are respectively fatigue strength and fatigue ductility exponent, and NR is the number of cycles to failure.

It is expected that isothermal LCF test condition yields the most conservative fatigue life prediction. However, it has been experimentally observed that the most conservative fatigue life may not be under isothermal test conditions but under TMF where combined cycles of both temperature and mechanical strains are applied (Halford, 1986; Viswanathan, 1989). The main damage mechanisms that operate under variable thermomechanical loading, as Sehitoglu (1992) proposes are fatigue, environmental attack (oxidation), and creep damage.

Depending on various material characteristics and operating conditions, one or more of these mechanisms may have the dominant contribution to the total damage. The CDM-based fatigue damage model, to be formulated in the next section, only considers the mechanical fatigue damage, which is dominant most of the time. In conditions where the other damage mechanisms have also a considerable role, the proposed model only accounts for the mechanical fatigue damage part of the total damage.

For preliminary design of mechanical components, subjected to complex loadings, the coupling of strain behavior with damage may be neglected and a post-processing of damage evolution is possible after a classical structural analysis. This approach, shown in Figure 1, is the uncoupled analysis based on a reference (visco-) plastic computation (Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005). This yields a lower bound on the number of cycles to rupture that is mostly a safe estimate regarding the integrity of the structure (Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005). In the case of thermomechanical loading, several studies have already shown that this coupling may not be necessary to perform reasonably predictive lifetime calculations (Thomas et al., 2004). Figure 1.
Uncoupled approach in structural damage analysis (Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005).

sec.title: The unified damage evolution law
sec.p: Lemaitre and Chaboche (Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005) proposed a damage evolution model for inter-granular fatigue cracking taking into account the effects of non-linear damage evolution and multi-axial stresses (2)dDdt=(YS)sp·,p>pD where S and s are the temperature-dependent damage material parameters, p is the accumulated plastic strain, Y is energy density release rate and pD is the threshold accumulated plastic strain. (3)Y=σeq2Rv2E(1-D)2,Rv=23(1+ν)+(1-2ν)(σHσeq)2 in which Rv is the triaxiality coefficient and σeq is the equivalent stress (4)σeq=(32SijSij)1/2,Sij=σij-σHδij,σH=12σkk
Finally, substitution of equations (3) and (4) in equation (2) gives (5)dDdt=(σeq2Rv2ES(1-D)2)sp·,p>pD

This law unifies many particular models: ductile damage if p· is governed by plasticity, creep damage if p· is given by a viscosity law, fatigue damage if p· is calculated from cyclic plasticity, quasi-brittle damage if p· is at a microscopic level (Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005). The failure or macrocrack initiation occurs when D=DC, where DC is critical damage parameter.

sec.title: The fatigue damage model
sec.p: CDM, which is known as an effective approach to model ductile failure, can be simply extended to the LCF damage processes (e.g. LCTF), where plasticity is still the key mechanism for the crack initiation (Bonora, 1998; Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005). According to equation (5), beyond the damage threshold (6)dD=(σeq2Rv2ES(1-D)2)sdp

In both LCF and LCTF, cyclic strain controlled fatigue occurs and the variation of stresses and strains typically leads to a hysteresis loop which rapidly stabilizes (Halford, 1986; Stephens et al., 2000; Viswanathan, 1989). Figure 2 shows a typical periodic strain-controlled loading of constant amplitude. To make the post-processing procedure faster, rather than simulating the whole fatigue life, it is only necessary to run the structural analysis up to the stabilized response. Figure 2.
Strain-controlled LCF: (a) cyclic strain range, (b) cyclic stress range and (c) stabilized hysteresis loop. LCF: low-cycle fatigue.
So, equation (6) could be integrated once over a cycle to give δD/δN and then over the whole process. (7)δDδN=∫1cycle(σeq2Rv2ES(1-D)2)sdp

Neglecting the variation of the damage over one cycle (8)δDδN=1(1-D)2s∫1cycle(σeq2Rv2ES)sdp,∫1cycle(σeq2Rv2ES)sdp=δD,Then,δDδN=δD(1-D)2s where δD is an expression of the cyclic damage evolution that will be calculated from the values of the stabilized stress behavior. To account for the non-isothermal condition of the thermomechanical loading, the material parameters dependencies on the temperature will be considered in the integration.

For the second integration (9)∫0DC(1-D)2sdD=δD∫NDNRdN or, (10)NR=ND+1δD(2s+1)(1-(1-DC)2s+1) NR gives the number of cycles to rupture, and ND is the number of cycles to reach the damage threshold (11)N=ND=pD2Δp→D=0 The threshold accumulated plastic strain, pD, depends on both the material and loading. For cyclic or fatigue loadings (Stephens et al., 2000; Viswanathan, 1989) (12)pD=ɛpD(σu-σy(σeqmax-σeqmin)/2-σy)m=ɛpD(σu-σyσM-σy)m ɛpD is the damage threshold plastic strain in pure tension and m is the damage threshold exponent. And Δp is the accumulated plastic strain increment over half of a cycle (13)Δp=12∫1cyclep·dt

As the non-isothermal condition exists, pD has different values during a cycle. Consequently, damage evolution does not have a specific threshold cycle but a transition period (cycles) lasts in the process until a fully started damage evolution occurs. Nevertheless, to be on the safe side, ND should be calculated using the minimum pD in the cyclic temperature range. However, ND is mostly negligible in comparison with the total number of cycles to rupture, NR (Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005).

Again, as the non-isothermal condition exists, DC (as the failure criterion) has different values in the process temperature range. However, as the damage parameter reaches the minimum DC which is related to the maximum temperature, a macrocrack is expected to be suddenly initiated for the first time. So, to be on the safe side the minimum DC should be selected.
The damage evolution law could be integrated such that it gives the damage evolution with respect to the number of cycling (14)D=1-[1-(n-ND)δD(2s+1)]1/(2s+1)

Equation (14) exhibits the non-linearity of the damage evolution observed in experiments (Askari, 2009). This equation could be easily extended to the conditions of VAL as a fatigue damage accumulation rule. This rule can take the load sequence and mean stress effects into account due to the inherent non-linearity of CDM (Chen et al., 1998). Considering the VAL of stress amplitudes of Δσ1a, Δσ2a, Δσ3a,…, Δσma with number of cyclings of n1, n2, n3,…, nm, one can show (15)D=∑i=1i=mDi=m-∑i=1i=m[1-(ni-NDi)δD(2s+1)]1/(2s+1) where NDi is zero if the accumulated plastic strain, p, up to the end of the previous block is greater than pDi. Otherwise, it is calculated using equations (11) to (13). It is notable, if ni is less than NDi, it means the ith block only causes the accumulation of plastic strain and no damage evolution occurs (Di=0).

Figure 3 schematically shows the damage evolution process of a typical three-blocked VAL in which the damage evolution starts in the first loading block and continues in the next ones. Damage evolution starts after ND1 cycles from point “A” and continues to point “B” up to n1 cycles under Δσ1a. At the same damage value, D1, damage evolution curve changes through “B” to “C” and reaches to point “D” after the next n2 cycles under Δσ2a. Another curve change happens at D=D2 through “D” to “E” where the last loading block, Δσ3a, starts and lasts for n3 cycles up to the failure point “F” with the damage value D3=DC. Figure 3.
Damage evolution curve.

sec.title: Case study: Engine exhaust manifold
sec.p: Exhaust manifolds are generally simple cast iron or stainless steel units which collect engine exhaust from multiple cylinders and deliver it to the exhaust pipe. In order to decrease the pollutant emission and fuel consumption of vehicles, exhaust systems are becoming more and more developed, often including advanced technical components such as very thin-walled and low-weight exhaust manifolds which lead to hotter exhaust fumes. Thus, to increase the durability and TMF resistance, exhaust manifolds are now widely made of stainless steel bent tubes or stamped shells steel (rather than cast iron) from grades with very good high temperature properties as well as formability (Schmitt et al., 2002; Yoon, 2004).

An exhaust manifold is generally subjected to many repeated run-stop cyclic loadings. Most of the cracks found in the stainless steel exhaust manifolds are caused by out-of-phase (OP) TMF, where the compressive strain occurs at high temperature. Although creep may have occurred at an elevated temperature, its effect on the fatigue life is relatively small because of the compressive state of strain. Therefore, the fatigue failure is dominated mainly by mechanical fatigue and plastic strain (Choi et al., 2004; Watanabe et al., 1998).

Highly loaded parts of engine systems are predominantly designed experimentally by means of long and expensive component tests. To decrease the development time and cost, computer simulation should be utilized which at the same time provides handling of the growing number of model variants and design optimization. This way, experiment is only needed at the end to verify the simulation results (Riedler et al., 2007; Thomas et al., 2004).

In this section, to demonstrate the capability and ease of use of the proposed model in the LCTF life assessment of industrial applications, a stainless steel engine exhaust manifold which is in early stages of design is assessed. For many steels, the lifetime under cyclic or thermocyclic loading is controlled by the formation and growth of microcracks (Jesus et al., 2004) which could be best described by CDM approach proposed in the previous section.

Typical thermomechanical loading subjected to an exhaust manifold during car lifetime is very difficult to define and is certainly not reproducible. Thus, a thermal shock loading which corresponds to severe running conditions will be used for the analysis instead.

sec.title: Analysis procedure
Finite element model
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the finite element model for the heat transfer and thermal stress analysis. It is composed of the exhaust manifold, simple cylinder head, bolts, gusset and the catalyst. Though the manifold is made of 1.5 mm thick bent tubes, it is constructed with two layered 8-node brick elements because the temperature difference between the outside and inside of the tubes imposes a high gradient through the thickness. The catalyst is modeled with shell elements and the cylinder head, bolts and the gusset are also modeled with brick elements. Figure 5.
Finite element model of the exhaust manifold.

In the design process, the austenitic stainless steel type 316 is selected for the material of the manifold (Askari, 2009). The widespread use of austenitic stainless steels in elevated temperature conditions indicates their attractive thermomechanical properties (Zamrik et al., 1996).

The mechanical and thermophysical properties of stainless steel 316 are respectively shown in Figures 6 and 7 (ASME, 2007) and Figure 8 shows the stress–strain curves at different temperatures (Tamarin, 2002). Figure 6.
Mechanical properties of stainless steel 316 (ASME, 2007).
Figure 7.
Thermophysical properties of stainless steel 316 (ASME, 2007).
Figure 8.
Stress–strain behavior of stainless steel 316 at different temperatures (Tamarin, 2002).

sec.title: Heat transfer analysis
sec.p: The objective of the heat transfer analysis is to determine the three dimensional temperature distribution in the exhaust system. This is a dominant step in life assessment process, because the accuracy of thermal data governs the accuracy of the mechanical response of the structure; therefore, the estimated fatigue (Thomas et al., 2004).

The input data are gas temperature and the internal heat exchange (convection) coefficient which come from gas flow simulation in the exhaust pipes in steady state, incompressible, and turbulent model (Askari, 2009). The temperature field is then calculated in a steady-state condition in a finite element code. Figure 9 shows the temperature field at the end of heating. The maximum temperature uniformly occurs in the manifold tubes, where the high temperature gas flows in a short thin-walled passage very fast. Figure 9.
Temperature field at the end of heating (°C).

sec.title: Thermal stress analysis
sec.p: In order to perform the elasto-plastic thermal stress analysis, it is necessary to consider the temperature distribution, mechanical constraints, and temperature-dependent material properties. The main stage of the loading is the thermal load and the only mechanical load is the bolt tightening which can be represented rather easily. The bottom surface of the simple cylinder head and the vertical supporting bolts of the catalyst are constrained.

The analysis is carried out in three steps with the same finite element model as for the thermal analysis; first, bolt pretension is applied, then the heating up and consequently cooling down processes of the thermal shock happen. The heating up and cooling down processes will be repeated for several cycles until the stabilized structural behavior is obtained.

Figure 10(a) and (([A-z]))b) shows the stabilized equivalent stress distribution in hot and cold conditions respectively. The equivalent plastic strain range is also shown in Figure 11. It can be seen that both the stress and plastic strain, which have the dominant effect on the damage evolution (refer to equation (7)), are maximum at the junctions (critical areas) where the expansion of the tubes is restricted by flanges and the cylinder head. Figure 10.
Equivalent stress distribution (MPa) at: (a) the hot and (b) cold conditions.
Figure 11.
Equivalent plastic strain range.

sec.title: Fatigue life prediction
sec.p:
Figure 12(a) and (([A-z]))b) shows the history of stress with respect to the mechanical strain and temperature at a typical point in the critical area up to the stabilized response. The highlighted closed loops A-B-C-D-A indicate the stabilized response of the structure under the heating up and cooling down process. In the critical area, large compressive plastic deformations are generated in run (hot) condition, and in stop (cold) condition, tensile stresses remain. The cyclic repetition of hot and cold conditions results in a thermal surface cracks which then progressively propagates through the thickness and failure happens. These phenomena originate mainly from the differences in stiffness and temperature between cylinder head and runners (Choi et al., 2004; Watanabe et al., 1998). Figure 12.
History of stress with respect to: (a) mechanical strain and (b) temperature.

In the following, the fatigue life of the manifold will be assessed using the CDM fatigue model presented in the previous section. This model suits the problem for two reasons. First, according to Figure 12(b), the maximum strain occurs at the minimum temperature and vice versa, and it is the sign of OP-TMF where the mechanical fatigue is the dominated failure mechanism. Second, for many steel-made components, the lifetime under cyclic or thermocyclic loading is controlled by the formation and growth of microcracks (Jesus et al., 2005), which could be best described by CDM.

Table 1 lists the damage parameters of stainless steel 316 at two different temperatures (20°C and 600°C). Table 1.
Damage parameters of stainless steel 316 (Lemaitre, 1992; Lemaitre and Desmorat, 2005).
T (°C) S (MPa) s Dc
20 7 1 0.15
600 0.2 1 0.5

Equations (8) to (14) are implemented in a computer program which automates the damage evolution and life assessment process in the whole model. The heat transfer and thermal stress analysis results as well as the temperature-dependent material properties are imported to this program. Neglecting the cycles up to the damage threshold (ND), the damage evolution of the critical point (Figure 12(a) and (([A-z]))b)) is shown in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Damage evolution curve.

The damage curve is intersected with the minimum DC line which is related to the maximum temperature during the thermal loading cycle. So, the fatigue life under the thermal shock is predicted as 528 cycles, which is quite less than the desired life of 1000 cycles under the considered thermal shock (Askari, 2009).So, the analysis reveals that some modifications are needed in the design of the manifold especially in the geometry of the junctions where the damage is localized. The sample manifold is under construction (Figure 14), which is going to be used for experimental purposes. Figure 14.
Under construction exhaust manifold sample.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
A fatigue model for LCTF was formulated in the framework of CDM based on a unified damage law presented by Lemaitre in which:
Non-isothermal condition of loading is taken into account through the temperature-dependent material parameters in the damage evolution integration.
Triaxiality and mean stress effects are included, damage accumulates non-linearly and a fatigue damage accumulation rule, which takes into account the load sequence effect, is presented.
The stabilized structural response under thermomechanical loading motivates the uncoupled analysis approach which makes the model a fast tool suitable for design purposes in the costly and time-consuming field of TMF life assessment.
LCTF life of a stainless steel engine exhaust manifold using the proposed model has been assessed which demonstrates the model implementation procedure.

Finally, it is recommended to adopt the model extension approach which is presented in this paper, for a damage model which takes into account the creep effect in order to present another LCTF model for the applications where the creep plays an important role.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This project was supported and funded by Research and Development of IRAN KHODRO car manufacturing company through agreement number 85400/136/1.
